The only thing these two songs have in common are the general rhythmic drum 
beat and instrumentation and the falsetto lead vocals all done in the same 
tempo.  The melody, bass lines, chord patterns and lyrics are ALL 
completely different. There is no plagiarism here....but to an ignorant 
jury, a skilled lawyer can convince them that if you glue wings on to a 
pig, it becomes a 747.  Thicke and Williams did not rip off Marvin Gaye's 
music....they just ripped off his style and his sound....both of which are 
not copyright nor patent protected under the law.﻿

Musicians and audiophiles hear the differences, and chalk it up (rightfully 
usually IMO) to influence, as everything is derivative to a degree. But 
drop it on a strategically chosen dumbed down jury, after hitting them with 
mind numbing long hours of techno-jargon from the same sharks, and they are 
gonna hear what they hear and it'll be "as the same". What do you expect? 
Most people in a crowd couldn't identify a bass line if the SVT8x10 rig 
fell on them, yet we let them decide on very subtle differences, of which 
they really aren't qualified, except in the end to say hey, "it sounds 
kinda the same to me".
Moral: If your song hits it big, it better not be derivative 
(subconsciously or not), because the bulls-eye is on your back.﻿

As someone who grew up playing music for most of my life, mainly classical, 
but pretty much all genres, can read it, write it etc. I wondered if this 
was a slippery slope. Pharrell is one of my fave producers, and he's famous 
for reaching back into other styles and genres and reimagining them in a 
compelling way, however I can see how the court could say this is similar 
on too many fronts. Inspiration is great and i'd venture to say that every 
song is an extension of the song that came before it, and before it, and 
before it, etc., and while clearly they aren't the same song, when it 
literally appears as if you went through a checklist in order to capture 
each facet and feel of the original song, then I suppose there is grounds 
for legal action. Basically it's overwhelmingly derivative.  Still love you 
though Pharrell! Not so much Thicke :)﻿

It's clear this judgement won't stand because the two songs are different 
at their core: the melodies and lyrics. What IS similar/exact is the beat 
(bass/drum). But, if the beat defined the song, then how far do you want to 
go - time signatures? All blues based music (about 95% of all music) has 
the same 4/4 count (and usually a 32 count repeatable pattern). There isn't 
enough room for creativity if the beat defines the song. It's only the 
melody that provides enough variation to be practical to copyright. Using 
the beat to define the song would be like using Rhythm and Meter in poetry 
to define the poem. Many poems use the same Rhythm/Meter. It's just a 
repeatable pattern just like the beat is in a song. What makes one song 
different from another is the combination of melody and lyrics. In these 
two songs, the lyrics are obviously different. And, although it takes an 
experienced ear to separate out the beat from the melody (something the 
decision makers in the current court case were.obviously .not trained for), 
if you overlay the melodies, you will see they are .different enough from 
one another to be considered different from a copyright perspective. An 
easy way to see this is to track the emotional inflections, which are 
clearly different for the two songs. Overlaying the actual notes of the 
melodies would be another way, although much harder since you'd have to 
have a transcription of the notes. One other thing that makes them sound 
similar is the party "atmosphere" in both. Again, this is not something you 
can copyright, having an "atmosphere" that is. The only infringement 
possible would be if they were exactly the same. Listen to the sounds of 
the party background and you'll see they are clearly different. Blurred 
Lines uses a lot "wooooo" and "hey". Got To Give It Up uses mostly 
unintelligible conversations. Between the beat being the same and the 
background being similar sounding (but not the same) an untrained ear could 
think they are the same (some people have a hard time separating out the 
melodies of two songs having the same bass/drum line). One last thing. 
Someone mentioned "sampling" but I don't believe that is an issue here 
since I didn't hear any but if there was any, "sampling, that IS legal and 
there is plenty of legal precedent for that. My guess is that this will go 
to the Supreme Court and by that time, someone will actually make a musical 
comparison as per the above and over turn the current decision.﻿

All of the popular music in the US - any style, is rooted in the Blues. 
 Try to track down the author of some of those old Blues standards and you 
start to feel cheated.  Robert Johnson's "Love in Vain" is a note for note 
copy of Leroy Carr's "In the Evening, When The Sun Goes Down".  Blind Boy 
Fuller played his version of Blind Blake.  The Mississippi Sheiks wrote 
"Sitting On Top of The World" and you hear the same melody in a thousand 
songs.  The whole genre is built on stolen melodies!  What is disheartening 
though is that NO ONE ever gave credit where it was due.  Adding new lyrics 
to an existing melody doesn't make the song yours.  Nearly 100 years later 
you see the same thing with Rap and uncreative sampling.

What I think is sad about all of this is Thicke claims to be such a big fan 
of Marvin's, but he can't seem to find the room in his ego to give the true 
master his props.  I am not sure if Blurred Lines is a note for note copy, 
but I think there is enough theft from his catalog that this lawsuit was 
totally warranted.  Kudos to the Gaye family.  Never mind the money, maybe 
some of Thicke's fans will get on YouTube to check out Marvin and hear what 
true talent is!﻿

There are hundreds and hundreds of two chord songs like Blurred Lines.  
Ironically, this Marvin Gaye song is not one of them.
The only similarities between the two songs are the tempos, the cowbell 
patterns, and the falsetto voices -all three of which are common, and each 
are lifted from somewhere else.  The chord progressions are completely 
different, as are the melodies for the vocals.  The Gaye family was banking 
on the hope that they would find a judge who knew nothing whatsoever about 
music...and they found one.

As for the sample issue: obviously Blurred Lines did not sample the other 
song, because there is no annoying fake party crowd shouting through it 
-which, ironically, is a Parliament rip off, which, in turn, is a James 
Brown rip off, who in turn is a Ray Charles/Sam Cooke rip off.

I'm just glad that the Gaye family got the justice it deserved: to get paid 
for a person's work which they had  absolutely nothing to do with, over an 
issue that took them two years to realize how outraged they were.﻿

what anti-rape critics could not by seeking to ban Robin Thicke and

Well, I wasn't even aware of this controversy until I stumbled upon it by 
accident. I listened/watched both videos side by side and he did indeed 
sample it or at least duplicate certain sections pretty closely enough to 
warrant further inspection. "I used to go out to parties" and then the 
rapper comes in.  MG's song begins, "I used to go out to parties", and the 
instrumentation and rhythm is VERY close.  That opening line told me all I 
needed to know.  If it's a true sample, then compensation needs to be 
made.  Details like cowbells and such (as one poster commented) are 
irrelevant, in my opinion. If you remake "Alien", but show clip samples 
from the original movie in your own movie, or simply "massage" the script 
to your own ends, you're not creating anything original and you certainly 
have little to defend yourself against any major lawsuits.  It appears to 
me as just another sampling with some rapping thrown in.  Nothing ground 
breaking, but it's not the end of the world.  I hope they can sort it out.﻿

in the way Sam Smith did with Tom Petty (and they STILL give him tons of 
grammy's??? which was note to note) and emulating a song without using a 
single piece of identical music.  Although I greatly dislike Robin Thicke 
and think it was cheap and my knee-jerk reaction would to be happy about 
this because of that, it still sets a horrible precedent for music, because 
the nature of plagiarism is in explicitly ripping things off, not giving 
them a nod.  All the money gleaned from the entire blues scale should then 
go to maybe Robert Johnson where the estates of greats like Buddy Guy would 
have to pay him... no way!  Yes, this is a terrible song, but it doesn't 
directly rip off anything in the actual music of the great Marvin Gaye even 
if it's close.  There is a difference between cheesy distasteful cheap 
emulation and actual stolen melodies.  The stolen melodies should always be 
dealt with as in the case of Sam Smith, that boring bastard, but never let 
the awfulness of pop impinge upon the integrity of overall music even if 
it's to show how it sucks.﻿

in "blurred lines" the bass note leading into the IV chord falls on the + 
of 4, in "got to give it up" the bass note falls on the + of 3 and a V 
chord tone falls on the + of 4. based on just this alone: different 
rhythmic syncopation, diifferent bass line melody, and different chord 
progression, there is no case here. now lets take a deeper look at the 
chord progressions: "blurred lines" is alternating between I-V pretty much 
the entire song with the bass line walking down from V to I in the 
turnaround. "got to give it up" is a I-IV-V-ii-IV-V progression. this 
lawsuit is a joke.﻿

To those of you who do not like Blurred Lines because of the content, you 
have every right to not like the song. But for those of you who are glad 
that the song was the subject of a lawsuit, think of the precedent this 
sets. In the future, we will get to the point where the general feel of a 
song can be copyrighted. Think of what that will do to music. It will be 
confined to an extremely limited area of creation. Artists will be afraid 
to write for fear of being sued. While it might not happen any time in the 
near future, legal precedents are hard to overturn, and this is a 
particularly dangerous one.﻿

I'm a musician, and I have listen to both of these songs numerous times, 
and they only have the beat and a few other similarities. There is no 
copyright infringement at all. They may have even been directly influenced 
by Gaye's song. In fact, they may have even deliberately tried to sound 
like this Marvin Gaye song, with its unique sound. But even if they did, 
there is no rip off, and more than if a bluegrass group writes a song in 
the bluegrass style. It's just a style. But there was no rip off of melody 
or lyrics, which is what would be required for them to have been found 
guilty. Many years ago Bo Diddley sued the Rolling Stones over there song 
"Not Fade Away." This song did use a rhythm similar to to Bo's, but the 
judge ruled that you can't copyright a beat.

My personal opinion is that the jury made the wrong call. I can see 
obviously similarities in some of the notes, particularly at the start, but 
only enough to prove that they were influence by Gaye's style of music and 
maybe this song in particular. It is not what I would call a direct copy 
under any circumstances, and they way the two songs were compared in court 
sounds shady at best: While Blurred Lines was played normally, the version 
of Got to Give It Up that was heard by the jury was not the final song, but 
was a recording based on the original sheet music with a lot of elements - 
notably the vocals - left out. This could make the songs sound more similar 
than they really are. Again, seems suspicious to me.

This doesn't mean I like either of the artists involved, or the song 
itself. I just don't believe there is enough evidence to prove they ripped 
off Gaye's song.﻿

Will Madonna sue Lady Gaga? Will George Clinton sue OutKast? Will Prince 
sue Bruno Mars, Beyonce, Justin Timberlake and umpteen-hundred others? And 
then will Little Richard sue Prince?

These idiotic questions became frighteningly legitimate after a federal 
jury in Los Angeles ruled that singer Robin Thicke and producer Pharrell 
Williams had committed copyright infringement. The jurors decided that yes, 
Thicke’s 2013 chart-topping single “Blurred Lines” had copied elements of 
Marvin Gaye’s 1977 hit “Got to Give It Up,” and awarded Gaye’s family a 
walloping $7.4 million. The titles of the two songs in question could not 
have been more fitting.

But it was the lack of detail on exactly which elements were copied that 
prompted a hard-swallow across all of popland on Tuesday night.

The jury was instructed to make its ruling based on written melodies, 
chords and lyrics, not the sounds of the respective recordings. If that’s 
the case, how these eight jurors arrived at their verdict is 
incomprehensible. Yes, “Blurred Lines” approximates the rhythm and timbre 
of “Got to Give It Up,” but is that theft?

Listen. Both songs have cowbell-ish percussion that plunkity-plunks at a 
similar tempo, but the patterns are different. Both songs have rich, 
teasing basslines, but the notes and rhythms of each are dissimilar.

“Blurred Lines” contains the phrase “Shake your rump, get down, get up-a,” 
while Gaye’s song includes the line, “Move it up, turn it ’round, shake it 
down” — but that’s about it, in terms of lyric parallels.

Sure, both recordings are filled with background chatter, as if they were 
cut at a party. And in direct homage, “Blurred Lines” is littered with 
steam-whistle WOO!s — one of Gaye’s vocal trademarks.

But while “Blurred Lines” might lack imagination, Thick and Williams 
ultimately only seem guilty of stealing a vibe.

And if vibes are now considered intellectual property, let us swiftly 
prepare for every idiom of popular music to go crashing into juridical 
oblivion. Because music is a continuum of ungovernable hybridity, a 
dialogue between generations where the aesthetic inheritance gets handed 
down and passed around in every direction. To try and adjudicate influence 
seems as impossible as it does insane. Is that the precedent being set here?

These songs are not in the same key.... whoever created this mash-up 
lowered the pitch of Got To Give It Up to match Blurred Lines. Different 
melody, lyrics, chord progression, key, and bass line. That leaves us feel 
and tempo. You can't copyright a metronome setting of ¼ note = 123 bpm. If 
this became criteria for copyright infringement, Marvin Gaye's estate would 
be on the hook to the composers of the thousands of songs at that tempo 
written prior to his. 

If it just comes down to feel, then practically every song ever written, 
every blues shuffle, every funk tune, every metal tune, every waltz, every 
swing tune, every bluegrass tune, every dance tune, (the list could go on 
endlessly) is infringing on copyright. I want to make it clear that I am 
NOT a fan of Robin Thicke, Pharrel Williams, or this song. I’m just a 
musician. This sets a terrible precedent.    ﻿

When the possible suit reared its ugly head ages ago, I listened to both 
songs and didn’t think “Blurred lines” sounded like a copy or plagiarism at 
all. Similar *feel* yes, r ‘n’ b, yes, falsetto vocals, yes… but not a rip 
off.

Before I go any further, ‘technically’, a song is only the lyric and the 
melody a-Capella style, while everything else is accompaniment, arrangement 
and production, enhancements of some sort or other. Factual example: I can 
write both parts, gain copyright in both and stand on a street corner sing 
them without any instrumental/arrangement *feel* of the song…which appear 
to have been the problem in this case. Equally, someone else can write a 
lyric while I compose a melody and we both own 50% of the song copyright. A 
production is a different matter and “Blurred lines” doesn’t sound like a 
production infringement either. 

Were any/all of the jury composed of musicians? Were there proper 
musicologist illustrating the differences? I very much doubt it! I have the 
same chords as the Marvin Gaye song in a couple of mine. So what? A song is 
‘technically’ the lyric and the melody…what the singer actually sings. One 
is a 4 chord song and the other a 2 chord song but although the *feel* of 
the 2 songs are similar, the melodies and lyrics are different.

Well, if that’s worthy of a lawsuit, then everyone who uses the old 1, 6, 4 
and 5/1, 6, 2 and 5 or 1, 4 and 5 (numbers used instead of Roman numerals 
for non-musicians/beginners) chord progression ought to get sued by 
someone. Almost all rhythm and blues songs from way back when have those, 
similar 1, 3, 5 arpeggio bass lines with 4’s or 8’s feel with a vamping 
piano and a middle 8 starting on the iv (4th for non-musicians/beginners) 
chord.﻿

Copyright is for melodic lines. Usually it's only the first 8 notes that 
can be similar, and after those 8 notes, then it's plagiarism. 
Rhythm/meter....drum beats there are only so many patterns that can be 
used. Look at most rap music, the drum beats are always basic and never 
changing it's almost nauseating listening to that for the whole song. 
It's just a basic drum beat beginners would learn. Any music in general, 
drum beats can only be so different and there are not a lot of different 
choices to have. Melodies are different than rhythm. Rhythm and meter 
basically mark the movement of the piece. Melody is the "singable" part of 
the song that people sing along to. People don't sing out the meter or the 
rhythm generally. With these two songs, the Marvin Gaye did not invent that 
beat -people used that beat way before he did. It's like trying to invent a 
new form of music. Any music now in days the form has been done 
already just small examples: Baroque, Classical, Romantic, Expressionism, 
Simplistic and etc. So these people are basically claiming that he made up 
a unique beat or rhythm. And centuries before him people used those same 
rhythmic patterns. If people start suing for drum beats, meter, rhythmic 
patterns, etc. Then music in general cant be created because those are the 
bones for music besides form. There are only so many options.﻿

You know, 100 years ago music composition required knowledge of music 
theory. Many (not all) current musicians know very little (if anything) 
about chord structure, chord progression, etc. They write and perform by 
ear, and that's ok, but the problem it creates is an environment where most 
inspiration comes from something that was heard by an artist, who in turn 
ad libs until they have something they think is original. But with little 
to no actual musical (theory) ability, their only choice is to pull again 
from sources they've already heard, maybe even without realizing. There is 
bound to be overlap, and I'm sure most people would agree it happens all 
the time. In my opinion, there is no possible way to address the issue as a 
whole, so the only plausible solution is to determine if it was INTENTIONAL 
on a case by case basis. If there wasn't intent, sorry Marvin, that's life. 
If they admitted they used his song as inspiration, then they should have 
paid royalties to use his work.

Between the two songs, he kick is the same, the cowbell is very different, 
the bass line has the exact same tone, but it's a different bass line. In 
the Marvin song, the cowbell is fatter, higher in the mix, and is slower. 
The Thicke song has a thinner, more offbeat, staccato cowbell. Even though 
the bass tone is identical, the bass line in the Thicke song follows 
different chords, fewer chords, actually, I think only three. The Marvin 
bassline stops and plays with a Major 2nd chord for a few bars before 
moving on. So..... The Robin Thicke crew sat down and analyzed the Marvin 
song very carefully, but did NOT sample it.﻿

As a musician/soundman... the songs are *both* in the exact same key... and 
have the same rhythmic pattern.  Yes, the lyrics/melody are a *bit* 
different... this is known in the writing world as "plagiarism".  While it 
is commonplace in the music "industry", it still doesn't excuse an outright 
ripoff... and begs the question of the "creativity" of both Thicke and 
Williams.  Yes, there are only 7 notes.  Yes, shit tends to get 
"recycled".  Still - this is plainly a case where the newer artist couldn't 
even invest the effort to change up a progression in a way to "make it 
their own"... eg, they were suffering from creative constipation, probably 
under the gun for a record company deadline, too high to do anything else 
but blatantly rip off a classic.
This is what happens when the "music business" (I'm talking about label 
reps here) insist on forcing "creativity" with a specific timeline for 
monetary gain.﻿

You guys aren't getting the point. It is very clear that Blurred Lines is 
inspired by Marvin Gaye, but inspiration has never ever been grounds for 
royalties or copyright. You have to give credits for sampling another 
artist, but this is not a sample, it's just
A similar background track. The key and chords are very similar, but 
previous legal precedents set by early jazz musicians on the practice of 
contradict has proven this to be legally irrelevant. No case can be made 
for lyrical or melodic similarities, so it's all in the groove, so let's 
look at that: The similarities are that A. The drum beat is pretty much the 
same B. The bass plays similar notes that are put in a sparse, but 
consistent place in the measure and C. There is in fact a cowbell groove 
present.

All of these points are invalid however, because the drum beat is such a 
commonly used one with no distinctive qualities and has been used it 
countless other songs. The bassline is conceptually the same, but 
rhythmically and melodically different which has never constituted 
copyright infringement and finally, the cowbell grove is rhythmically 
completely different. Like completely.

For those of you that think they are different... Both songs are identical 
in key, identical in chord progression, identical in time signature, and 
have almost identical tempo. The drums are different only in that there is 
an additional note with the cowbell in the drum track. If you were to 
isolate blurred lines and remove the vocal tracks, and then overlay Marvin 
Gaye's version, you would have virtually the same song. Which is what was 
presented to the jury and they agreed after seeing the evidence. That 
pretty much spells out plagiarism. ﻿

progressions. Variations of percussions are even confined to patterns we 
identify as rhythm or rhythmic steps. It is not surprising every song ever 
made has some relationship to some other song. Most modern music today has 
deep routs in classical music. Why does this song differ from any other 
song. I feel the creativity and delivery of a song is just as copyrightable

influences' family suing the Gaye family because Marvin was influenced by 
someone else. Does that constitute an infringement? Well if this sets a 
presidency for others to follow I gather we are in for some paradigm shift 
in music or everyone is going to start suing everyone. That leaves me with 
a uncomfortable thought that new music is going to be shit. I personally 
choose to like songs because they fit into what I like. Not becuase they 
are new and I never experienced it before and decide that it's what I like. 
A hit song is based on what people would like and that model of what we 
would like is already established by previous genre, sounds, musical 
progressions, and even bass lines. Only what is new is the lyrics. Words

I don't side with the masses on this one. It's wrong and Gaye' family is 
wrong and the courts should step in and correct this injustice. ﻿

If you displace where the "1" is felt, and you rerecord the parts, I don't 
think you should have to pay royalties, even if the drum pattern is 
otherwise exact, because essentially the entire song gets moved at least a 
sixteenth, and there were no samples. Rhythmic displacement is a viable 
compositional tool, and is not the same as a sample. Just because something 
sounds similar doesn't mean it's a cover; but I didn't think Harrison 
should have had to pay for "My Sweet Lord" either-- but I did think 
Harrison should pay before I learned to play. I think it is impossible to 
"teach" a jury what is necessary to make an appropriate musical decision, 
and famous individuals end up having to make huge payouts (which may not be 
justified) because of social justice sentimentality. Are musicians and 
their descendents ripped off? Sure. Should Pharrell et al be expected to 
pay off simply because they were convenient targets? No. Every popular bass 
line today has come from somewhere else; all music is derivative. I think 
it sets a bad legal precedent.﻿

Okay, so the percussion rhythm is the same, the bass uses the same note 
lengths, and both vocals make heavy use of falsetto. Oh, and both songs 
make use of the I, IV, and V chords at some point (shocking, I know).

The vocal has a different melody with totally different phrasing. The 
chords progress differently. The harmonic rhythm is different. Plus Got to 
Give It Up has a much more active bass. And that's not even mentioning the 
actual lyric content.

What was copied was a feel. Should we accuse every funk tune of plagiarism? 
What about Country? Reggae? Bebop, Latin, Afro-Cuban, and Swing? Disco?? 
All of these styles are practically *defined* by what the rhythm section is 
doing, or "the beat" as you youngsters call it. Does that mean every 
composer of these styles is guilty of plagiarism?

NO!

What makes a song distinct within its genre is the combination of melody, 
phrasing, and chord progression. All musicians stand upon the shoulders of 
those who came before them, playing in their styles but with something new 
to say. Copying "the beat" is not only common, but encouraged. It's been 
done even since before Dixieland for crying out loud!

Don't get me wrong now, I hate the song "Blurred Lines" and would feel very 
much schadenfreude in seeing Thicke taken down, but this is simply 
ridiculous. These songs are very definitely not the same, and to say 
otherwise is an insult to Marvin Gaye's amazing musical talent. Go complain 
about country songs.﻿

A real simple way to determine if this is plagiarism or not is to isolate 
the melodies from the background tracks and then compare the melodies to 
each other. So simple it is. Backing tracks, i.e. drum beat, bass riff, the 
sound of the overall production CAN NOT BE COPYRIGHTED. The actual 
performance of any given track is owned by the musician or who ever hired 
him, hence suits in regards to sampling. That is not the case here. 
The decision here will hopefully be repealed after a new suit is filed.

George Harrison's "My Sweet Lord" borrowed much less from The Chiffon's 
"He's So Fine," yet Harrison lost in court and had to give credits to The 
Chiffons. Similarly, The Beach Boys "Surfin' USA" also borrowed from Chuck 
Berry's "Sweet Little Sixteen," and had to give him writing credits. The 
bass line in "Blurred Lines" borrowed extensively from Gaye's "Got To Give 
It Up," as are the percussion lines which have only minor differences. 
There are far more similarities in Pharrell's and Thicke's song than in a 
Harrison-Chiffons comparison or Beach Boys-Chuck Berry comparison, in which 
a simple riff in "My Sweet Lord" seemed borrowed from "He's So Fine," as is 
the case of the BBs and Berry. One of the posters in this thread says he's 
been recording/playing for 41 years and another one says he's been 
producing music for video games (now there's a challenge), so they are the 
"experts" in this category. Sorry, but I've been singing/writing/recording 
for several labels for the past 51 years and copyright law says that when 
you borrow from one song, whether it be just a signature riff or lyric 
lines or whatever, you HAVE PLAGIARIZED. Marvin Gaye should get writing 
credits for "Blurred Lines" based on the interpretation of the law as 
applied in the "He's So Fine" and "Sweet Little Sixteen" cases.﻿

bandwagon when someone pointed out 'hey that kinda sounds like *this*, 
doesn't it?'... and they decided after they met with a few 'experts' that 
it could be a lucrative endeavor.


Therefore, in retrospect, shouldn't half the music artists out there be 
suing each other over and over (most would be sued and be sued 
consecutively). The same goes with vehicle body styles, painting, 
sculpting...the list goes on. Nobody is ripping off Marvin's creative 
genius; this was carried out because there was a possibility it could be 
won (not because it was the truth) and an opportune time for opportunists.﻿

I grew up in the decades when Marvin Gaye (the Legend) was performing.  I 
have listened numerous times to both Got To Give It Up and Blurred Lines 
and while I hear some similarly in the beat and timing they are NOT the 
same.  There have tens of thousands of songs over the past 50 years of 
which many had some similarities with other songs… I lived through all 
those decades so I have heard a good number of them.  There are only so 
many possibilities and no one ‘owns’ a selection of notes. If that were the 
case most have had notes and melodies ‘plagiarized’ from the classical 
composers.  I have heard many songs that have snippets of classical music 
woven into songs or ones that actually start with a classical intro… 
example: does anyone remember ‘Sweetbox’? A lot of their lyrics were set to 
actual classical compositions. There have been lots of others.  Maybe all 
those artists should be paying royalties to the estates and families of 
Mozart, Back, Beethoven, etc.﻿
